awd_titl_txt: Testing the Validity of Inner-magnetosphere Shielding by the Region-2 Field-aligned Currents
awd_abstract_narration:
The outer layers of the Earth's atmosphere interact with the solar wind. Scientists still do not understand the process of how energy is transported from the solar wind throughout each of these layers of low-density, plasmas. This work investigates how these energy transport processes occur from the magnetosphere into the ionosphere. The project is relevant to the National Space Weather Action Plan since it will assist in identifying typical limits of ionospheric disturbances generated from extremes of observed space weather effects. These disturbances affect the orbits of satellites that can compromise tracking and operations of our US commercial and defense assets. An early career scientist and undergraduate researchers will be supported.

The shielding electric field generated due to charge separation associated with the Region-2 Field Aligned Currents (FAC) plays an important role in determining the dynamics of the coupled inner magnetosphere-ionosphere system. However, the paucity of global-scale measurements of field-aligned currents and electric fields in the sub-auroral region has restricted our understanding of the dynamics of inner magnetosphere shielding and several questions remain unanswered. Specifically, (1) To what extent is the paradigm of shielding valid?, (2) What are the timescales associated with shielding?, and (3) How do season and local time influence shielding? The overarching goal of this work is to answer these questions by using measurements from the NSF-funded Active Magnetosphere and Planetary Electrodynamics Response Experiment (AMPERE) dataset to determine the imbalance between the Region-1 and Region-2 FACs as a proxy for the intensity of shielding. Specific tasks will focus on combining AMPERE FACs with electric fields from the mid-latitude Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN) to determine the extent to which the paradigm of inner magnetosphere shielding by Region-2 FACs is valid and to determine the modulating influence of ionospheric conductivity and MLT on the magnitude, extent and timescales of over-/under-shielding electric fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project was to develop an improved understanding of how electric fields and field-aligned currents in the charged component of the Earth’s upper atmosphere ( the “ionosphere”) are controlled by interplanetary conditions determined by solar activity. Large-scale masurements of electric fields from Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN) radars and Field-Aligned Currents (FACs) from the Active Magnetosphere and Planetary Electrodynamics Response Experiment (AMPERE) are the primary data sources to be used in this study. The research activities carried out by the PI and Co-I produced multiple journal articles and several conference presentations. In addition, the PI during the time period of the project gained teaching experience and taught several courses for the Electrical & Computer Engineering department at Virginia Tech. Lastly, the PI also mentored undergraduate and graduate students which produced journal articles directly relevant to the project. The main scientific results are summarized in the next paragraphs. 


A deep learning based approach for modeling the dynamics of AMPERE Birkeland currents 


 In this study, Dr. Kunduri has analyzed the behavior of the Birkeland current system using several years (Jan 2010 to Dec 2016) of data from the Active Magnetosphere and Planetary Electrodynamics Response Experiment (AMPERE). The data was used to develop the first application of deep learning architecture for modeling the Field-aligned currents. The model uses a 1-hour time history of IMF & solar wind parameters as inputs to determine the global distribution of Birkeland currents. The model provided important insights into inner magnetosphere shielding and showed the development of currents in response to changes in IMF and solar wind.


Reference:

Kunduri, B. S. R., Maimaiti, M., Baker, J. B. H., Ruohoniemi, J. M., Anderson, B. J., & Vines, S. K. (2020). A deep learning based approach for modeling the dynamics of AMPERE Birkeland currents. Journal of Geophysical Research: Space Physics, 125, e2020JA027908. https://doi.org/10.1029/2020JA027908 


Dr. Kunduri also contributed towards another project which involved the development of a deep learning model for forecasting the onset of magnetic substorms. The study presented the first deep learning-based approach to predict the onset of a magnetic substorm, defined as the signature of the auroral electrojets in ground magnetometer measurements. 


Reference:
Maimaiti, M., Kunduri, B., Ruohoniemi, J. M., Baker, J. B. H., & House, L. L. (2019). A deep learning-based approach to forecast the onset of magnetic substorms. Space WeatherSpace Weather, 17, 1534–1552. https://doi.org/10.1029/2019SW002251 


Determining the role of ionosphere-thermosphere system in driving sub-auroral plasma convection  

Plasma convection at the sub-auroral latitudes plays an important role in determining the dynamics of the coupled sub-auroral and inner magnetospheric region. In this study, we analyzed observations of electric fields extending across the North American sector observed during a period of enhanced geomagnetic driving.  Our observations suggest that the mid-latitude trough plays a crucial role in determining the location of sub-auroral plasma convection as well as sustaining these flows long after the magnetospheric driver has turned off, during this event.  

Reference:

Kunduri, B. S. R., Baker, J. B. H., Ruohoniemi, J. M., Coster, A. J., Vines, S. K., Anderson, B. J., et al. (2021). An examination of magnetosphere-ionosphere influences during a SAPS event. Geophysical Research Letters, 48, e2021GL095751. https://doi.org/10.1029/2021GL095751 


Quiet time mid-latitude SuperDARN backscatter classification using ray-tracing and neural networks  

During geomagnetically quiet conditions, the mid-latitude SuperDARN radars commonly see a variety of low‐velocity plasma drift whose velocity and spectral width profiles are very similar to ground scatter. Such low-velocity ionospheric scatter is important to understanding mid-latitude ionospheric electrodynamics, and the traditional method for backscatter classification has proven to be less effective at identifying such events. In this study, we present a new technique for the classification of mid-latitude SuperDARN data using ray-tracing and neural networks. The quiet-time ionospheric scatter that is identified through this method can be applied to develop statistical characterization of ionospheric backscatter and examine the degree of "leaky" shielding at mid-latitudes. 

Reference:

Kunduri, B. S. R., Baker, J. B. H., Ruohoniemi, J. M., Thomas, E. G., & Shepherd, S. G. (2022). An examination of SuperDARN backscatter modes using machine learning guided by ray-tracing. Space Weather, 20, e2022SW003130. https://doi.org/10.1029/2022SW003130


Storm Time Electrified MSTIDs Observed Over Mid‐Latitude North America  

Dr. Kunduri worked closely with a graduate student to analyze the role of mid-latitude electric fields in driving storm-time Medium Scale Traveling Ionospheric Disturbances (MSTIDs). Storm-time electrified MSTIDs have recently been linked with penetration electric fields and inner magnetosphere sheilding during geomagnetic storms. Understanding their driving mechanisms is important to understand storm-time electrodynamics. This work resulted in a journal publication and the student graduated with a Master’s thesis.  

Reference:

Kelley, I. J., Kunduri, B. S. R., Baker, J. B. H., Ruohoniemi, J. M., & Shepherd, S. G. (2023). Storm time electrified MSTIDs observed over mid-latitude North America. Journal of Geophysical Research: Space Physics, 128, e2022JA031115. https://doi.org/10.1029/2022JA031115
